crops.description: One of the best pasture grasses in India, each plant producing a dense mass of fine stems a foot or more high. It produces seed in great abundance. Distribution: Southern Europe and Asia, extending from Italy eastward through Greece, Asia Minor, and northern Persia to India; also in Egypt, Abyssinia, and South Africa.
An annual grass that may be valuable after the manner of crab-grass. Distribution: Found throughout the tropical region of India and is generally distributed in the Tropics of both hemispheres.
Said to be one of the best pasture legumes in India. Distribution: Throughout India from the Himalayas to Ceylon; also in Abyssinia, Afghanistan, the Malay Archipelago, and northern Australia.
A tall, erect species being tested for hay at Kirki. Distribution: Throughout the plains of British India.
Similar to our common crab-grass. Distribution: Not specified.
A creeping species abundant in sorghum, etc., at Kirki. The green pods are eaten by boys. Distribution: Throughout the plains of India and in Abyssinia.

A rather coarse grass, but cut for fodder. Distribution: Found on dry hills at the base of the Himalayas, where it rises to an elevation of 3,500 feet, in the Khasi Hills and southward in the Dekkan Peninsula of India; also in the States of North Australia and Queensland in Australia.
A prostrate legume abundant in the Dekkan, said to be good fodder. Distribution: Throughout the tropical region of India from the valley of the Ganges to Ceylon.

A large annual Panicum producing enormous panicles 12 to 18 inches long and nearly as broad. These panicles break off and drift over the country after the manner of tumbleweeds. The grass is considered fair forage. Distribution: From India eastward to China and Borneo, and in tropical Africa.
A tall, rather coarse grass growing on comparatively low ground. It makes only fair forage. Distribution: In the Central Provinces and in the Dekkan Peninsula of India.

A grass growing about Poona in more or less shaded places, especially where somewhat moist. Distribution: From the western Himalayas, where it rises to an elevation of 8,000 feet, southward to the Coromandel Coast of India, and eastward to the provinces of Chilli, Klangsu, Hupeh, and Yunnan in China; also in Nubla and Abyssinia in northern Africa.
A grass abundant throughout northern and central India and considered excellent forage. Much of it is cut for hay.
Very similar to the preceding, but with much more slender stems. Distribution: Throughout the plains and hills of India, and in tropical Africa, China, the Pacific islands, and in Australia.

Collected on wet banks. The leaves are like white clover and the scapes bear one or two bright-blue flowers. Distribution: From the alpine slopes of the Himalayas southward and eastward to Ceylon and Burma in India, and in the Malay Archipelago to Java, also in tropical Africa.

A perennial grass forming a considerable element of the grassy meadows. Distribution: In India on the temperate slopes of the Himalayas at an elevation of 5,000 to 10,000 feet, between Dalhousie and Bhutan and on the Khasi Hills.

An abundant element of the grassy meadows of the Nilgiri Hills and considered good forage. Distribution: In the drier parts of India from the lower Himalayas to Burma and Ceylon, and generally distributed in the Tropics of the Eastern Hemisphere.
Locally abundant in the grassy meadows of the Nilgiri Hills. Distribution: From the eastern part of India southeastward through the Malay Archipelago to China and Australia.
Common in shady places in the Nilgiri Hills at 6,000 feet altitude.
